label: Mentored
evidence: Andreae dedicated works to Hess including De Christiani Cosmoxeni genitura (1612). He wrote a memorial for Hess when he died in 1614 and referred to him in glowing terms as a mentor and father-figure.

label: Mentored
evidence: Besold encouraged Andreae's interest in esotericism and provided access to his large personal library of mystical and philosophical sources. They were close colleagues in the Tübingen Circle.

label: Spiritual influence
evidence: Andreae highly praised True Christianity and published Christianismus genuinus (1615) as a summary of Arndt's treatise. Arndt's practical spirituality deeply shaped Andreae's theological vision.

label: Close friends
evidence: Besold and Kepler were classmates at the University of Tübingen in the early 1590s. When Kepler's mother was accused of witchcraft in 1615, Besold helped in her legal defense.

label: Studied astronomy
evidence: Kepler studied at the University of Tübingen under Mästlin, who introduced him to Copernican astronomy. Mästlin was one of the few supporters of Copernicus at the time.

label: Studied mathematics
evidence: Andreae studied under Michael Mästlin at the University of Tübingen, placing him in the same intellectual context as Kepler.

label: Posthumous influence
evidence: Weigel's posthumously published writings on inner spirituality and the 'inner church' influenced Boehme's development of Christian theosophy.

label: Posthumous influence
evidence: Weigel's mystical writings influenced Arndt's devotional theology and emphasis on inner transformation.

label: Posthumous influence
evidence: Boehme adopted alchemical symbols and the Paracelsian three principles (salt, sulfur, mercury) to articulate his nature mysticism.

label: Spiritual influence
evidence: Franck's emphasis on the inner Word over external Scripture and doctrine influenced Weigel's development of spiritualist thought.

label: Spiritual influence
evidence: Schwenckfeld's works were collected by Karl Widemann and his spiritualist emphasis influenced Weigel's thought.

label: Posthumous influence
evidence: Gichtel was a major follower of Boehme who edited and published Boehme's collected works and founded the Gichtelians based on Boehme's teachings.

label: Angelic communications
evidence: Dee and Kelley collaborated on spiritual conferences and angelic communications from 1582. They traveled together through Central Europe seeking patronage until parting in 1589.

label: Met in Bremen
evidence: Khunrath met John Dee in Bremen on 27 May 1589 as Dee was returning to England. Khunrath later praised Dee in his writings.

label: Met at Prague court
evidence: After meeting Dee, Khunrath traveled to Rudolf II's court in Prague where he met Edward Kelley who had remained in Bohemia.

label: Received at court
evidence: Dee and Kelley first made contact with Rudolf II in Prague in 1583, seeking patronage for their esoteric work.

label: Court alchemist
evidence: After parting from Dee, Kelley remained in Bohemia as a prominent alchemist under Rudolf II's patronage until his imprisonment and death.

label: Physician and counselor
evidence: On 19 September 1609 Maier formally entered the service of Emperor Rudolf II as his physician and imperial counselor. He was elevated to hereditary nobility.

label: Imperial Astronomer
evidence: Tycho Brahe became Imperial Court Astronomer under Rudolf II in Prague from 1599 until his death in 1601.

label: Imperial Mathematician
evidence: Kepler succeeded Tycho Brahe as Imperial Astronomer under Rudolf II after Brahe's death in 1601.

label: Astronomical collaboration
evidence: Kepler joined Brahe as an assistant in Prague in 1600 and inherited his observational data after Brahe's death in 1601.

label: Hosted at Třeboň
evidence: Vilém of Rožmberk hosted John Dee and Edward Kelley at his castle in Třeboň, supporting their alchemical research.

label: Alchemical patron
evidence: Vilém of Rožmberk was a major patron of Edward Kelley at his castle in Třeboň.

label: Secretary
evidence: Karl Widemann briefly served as secretary to Edward Kelley at Rudolf II's court in Prague.

label: Intellectual polemic
evidence: Libavius published Analysis Confessionis (1615) criticizing the Rosicrucian manifestos. Fludd responded with Apologia Compendiaria (1616) and Tractatus Apologeticus (1617) defending the Brotherhood.

label: Appointed first chemistry professor
evidence: In 1609, Landgrave Moritz appointed Hartmann to a newly created chair for Chymiatrie at the University of Marburg—the first professorship explicitly dedicated to chemistry.

label: Court physician
evidence: Around 1619 Maier became physician to Landgrave Moritz of Hesse-Kassel.

label: Close association
evidence: Haslmayr had close ties to Benedictus Figulus and Karl Widemann and reportedly lived with them for a time.

label: Close association
evidence: Haslmayr had close ties to Karl Widemann and reportedly lived with them for a time.

label: Manuscript network
evidence: Figulus and Widemann were both active in collecting and preserving Paracelsian and esoteric manuscripts.

label: Rosicrucian initiation
evidence: Backhouse is reputed to have initiated Ashmole into Rosicrucian and alchemical knowledge around 1651.

label: Married
evidence: Frederick V married Elizabeth Stuart, daughter of King James I of England, in 1613.

label: Court connections
evidence: Maier had ties to Frederick V's court in Heidelberg as part of the Rosicrucian milieu.

label: Garden designer
evidence: Salomon de Caus designed the Hortus Palatinus at Heidelberg for Frederick V from 1611-1619.

label: Published works
evidence: Bodenstein published over 40 Paracelsian titles beginning in 1560, making Paracelsian texts widely available.

label: Brothers
evidence: Conrad Khunrath was the older brother of Heinrich Khunrath.

label: Principal author
evidence: Andreae is generally credited as the main author of the Fama Fraternitatis, though drawing on ideas from Tobias Hess and the Tübingen Circle.

label: Inspired content
evidence: Hess's ideas on Paracelsianism, chiliasm, and reformation echo throughout the Fama. He is seen as the catalyst/inspirer of the manifestos.

label: Principal author
evidence: Andreae is credited as principal author of the Confessio Fraternitatis.
Andreae explicitly acknowledged writing the Chymical Wedding of Christian Rosenkreutz.
Andreae wrote the utopian work Christianopolis.
Aurora was Boehme's first mystical work, written in 1612 and circulated in manuscript.
Boehme wrote Mysterium Magnum in 1623 as a mystical commentary on Genesis.
Gichtel edited and published Boehme's collected works, helping establish Boehme's enduring influence.
Arndt's Vier Bücher vom wahren Christentum was published in four books between 1605 and 1610.
Khunrath wrote Amphitheatrum Sapientiae Aeternae in 1595.
Maier published Atalanta Fugiens in 1617 in Oppenheim.
Croll wrote Basilica Chymica, published in 1609.
Fludd wrote Utriusque Cosmi Historia, published 1617-1621.
Fludd wrote Apologia Compendiaria in 1616 defending the Rosicrucian Brotherhood.
Dee wrote Monas Hieroglyphica in 1564.
Libavius wrote Alchymia in 1597, considered the first systematic chemistry textbook.
Libavius published Analysis Confessionis Fraternitatis de Rosea Cruce in 1615.
Ashmole compiled and published Theatrum Chemicum Britannicum in 1652.
Severinus wrote Idea Medicinae Philosophicae in 1571.

label: English translation
evidence: Thomas Vaughan, under pseudonym Eugenius Philalethes, translated the Fama and Confessio into English in 1652.

label: English translation
evidence: Thomas Vaughan translated the Confessio into English in 1652.

label: Defense against critique
evidence: Fludd's Apologia was written as a response to Libavius's Analysis attacking the Rosicrucian manifestos.

label: Critique
evidence: Libavius's Analysis was a systematic critique of the Confessio Fraternitatis.
Boehme lived and worked as a shoemaker in Görlitz from around 1599 until his death in 1624.

label: University studies
evidence: Andreae studied at the University of Tübingen and was part of the Tübingen Circle.
Hess was a jurist residing in Tübingen.

label: Professor of law
evidence: Besold was professor of law at the University of Tübingen.

label: University student
evidence: Kepler studied at the University of Tübingen.

label: Professor
evidence: Mästlin was professor of mathematics at the University of Tübingen.
Rudolf II made Prague his principal residence and center of his court.
Dee visited Prague seeking patronage from Rudolf II between 1583 and 1589.
Kelley remained in Prague and Bohemia after Dee's departure until his death.
Brahe moved to Prague in 1599 as Imperial Astronomer and died there in 1601.

label: Imperial Astronomer
evidence: Kepler worked in Prague as assistant to Brahe and then as Imperial Astronomer.
Maier moved to Prague in 1608 and served Rudolf II until around 1611.
Khunrath visited Rudolf II's court in Prague where he met Edward Kelley.
Frederick V's court was at Heidelberg from his succession in 1610 until he accepted the Bohemian crown.
Elizabeth Stuart lived at Heidelberg after her marriage to Frederick V in 1613.

label: Garden design
evidence: De Caus designed the Hortus Palatinus at Heidelberg from 1611-1619.

label: Chemistry professor
evidence: Hartmann was appointed professor of Chymiatrie at Marburg in 1609, the first such position.

label: Professor
evidence: Croll was a professor at Marburg.

label: Professor
evidence: Eglin became professor at Marburg from 1606 after fleeing Zürich.
Moritz was Landgrave of Hesse with his court at Kassel.
Fludd practiced medicine in London.
Ashmole lived and worked in London as an antiquarian.
Widemann was a physician based in Augsburg who conducted his manuscript collecting activities there.

label: Exile court
evidence: After his defeat, Frederick V spent the rest of his life in exile at The Hague.

label: Exile court
evidence: Elizabeth Stuart maintained court culture in exile at The Hague for decades after 1622.
Dee and Kelley were hosted by Vilém of Rožmberk at his castle in Třeboň.
Kelley lived at Vilém of Rožmberk's castle in Třeboň conducting alchemical work.

label: Publishing
evidence: Bodenstein worked in Basel publishing Paracelsian texts.

label: Medical degree
evidence: Maier earned his medical doctorate from the University of Basel in October 1596.

label: Intellectual circle
evidence: Mögling was connected to Andreae's intellectual circle and wrote Rosicrucian works in the same period.

label: Posthumous influence
evidence: Sennert sought to reconcile traditional Galenic medicine with Paracelsian innovations, integrating chemical remedies into academic medicine.

label: Thematic parallels
evidence: Bacon's New Atlantis (1627) has been linked to Rosicrucian ideals by scholars like Frances Yates. His project for advancement of learning aligned with manifesto themes, though direct involvement is debated.

label: Tübingen Circle
evidence: Hölzel was part of the wider Tübingen network of mystical and esoteric thinkers that included Andreae, Hess, and Besold.

label: Tübingen Circle member
evidence: Hölzel was associated with the Tübingen Circle centered at the university.

label: Patron and associate
evidence: Von Wense was a noble patron connected to esoteric and utopian circles including the Tübingen network around Andreae.

label: Mentor and father-in-law
evidence: Petraeus was Hartmann's son-in-law and collaborated with him at Marburg in presiding over academic disputations on Paracelsian medicine.

label: Son-in-law
evidence: Petraeus married Hartmann's daughter.

label: Academic
evidence: Petraeus worked at the University of Marburg, presiding over academic disputations.
Cramer wrote Societas Jesu et Rosae Crucis Vera, published by Lucas Jennis of Frankfurt in 1617.

label: Professor
evidence: Cramer held an academic position as professor at the University of Marburg, where he also wrote metaphysical works.

label: Publisher
evidence: Lucas Jennis of Frankfurt published Cramer's Rosicrucian emblem book in 1617.

label: Contemporary emblem authors
evidence: Both Cramer and Maier published Rosicrucian-themed emblem books in 1617 through Frankfurt publishers. Maier's Atalanta Fugiens and Cramer's Societas Jesu et Rosae Crucis Vera represent the flowering of Rosicrucian emblematic literature.

label: Published during furor
evidence: Cramer's 1617 emblem book was part of the wave of Rosicrucian publications that followed the manifestos.

label: Core member
evidence: Andreae was a core member of the Tübingen Circle and principal author of the Rosicrucian manifestos produced by the group.

label: Catalyst and founder
evidence: Hess was the catalyst and inspirer behind the Tübingen Circle. His ideas on Paracelsianism, chiliasm, and reformation shaped the group's vision and the Rosicrucian manifestos.

label: Key member
evidence: Besold was a close colleague in the Tübingen Circle, providing access to his vast library of mystical and philosophical sources.

label: Member
evidence: Hölzel was part of the wider Tübingen network of mystical and esoteric thinkers that produced the Rosicrucian manifestos.

label: Noble patron
evidence: Von Wense was a noble patron connected to the Tübingen Circle and its esoteric and utopian interests.

label: Headquarters
evidence: The Tübingen Circle was centered at the University of Tübingen, where its members studied and worked.

label: Created manifesto
evidence: The Tübingen Circle produced the Fama Fraternitatis, the first Rosicrucian manifesto.

label: Created manifesto
evidence: The Tübingen Circle produced the Confessio Fraternitatis, the second Rosicrucian manifesto.

label: Created allegorical work
evidence: The Chymical Wedding emerged from the Tübingen Circle, written by Andreae.

label: Central figure
evidence: The Boehme Circle gathered around Jacob Boehme in Görlitz, copying and circulating his manuscripts despite church opposition.

label: Later leader
evidence: Gichtel continued the Boehme Circle's work after Boehme's death, editing and publishing his collected works from Amsterdam.

label: Headquarters
evidence: The Boehme Circle was centered in Görlitz where Boehme lived and worked.

label: Principal collector
evidence: Widemann spent over 30 years collecting and copying manuscripts, preserving large portions of the Paracelsian corpus.

label: Editor and publisher
evidence: Figulus collected and edited Paracelsian works, publishing anthologies like Rosarium novum olympicum (1608).

label: Associate
evidence: Haslmayr had close ties to Figulus and Widemann and reportedly lived with them for a time, participating in their manuscript collecting activities.

label: Compiler
evidence: Eglin compiled alchemical handbooks preserving the social context and provenance of alchemical recipes. His network included Figulus and other collectors.

label: Center of activity
evidence: Widemann was based in Augsburg, making it a center of the manuscript collecting network.

label: Patron
evidence: Frederick V was the center of the Heidelberg intellectual circle, his court serving as a hub for Protestant reform hopes.

label: Patron
evidence: Elizabeth Stuart joined the Heidelberg circle after her marriage to Frederick V in 1613.

label: Court designer
evidence: De Caus designed the Hortus Palatinus at Heidelberg, considered to incorporate Hermetic symbolism.

label: Court location
evidence: The Heidelberg intellectual circle was centered at Frederick V's court in Heidelberg.

label: Exiled ruler
evidence: After his defeat at White Mountain, Frederick V maintained his court in exile at The Hague until his death in 1632.

label: Exiled queen
evidence: Elizabeth Stuart maintained court culture in exile at The Hague for decades after 1622.

label: Exile location
evidence: The exile court was maintained at The Hague in the Netherlands.

label: Announces brotherhood
evidence: The Fama Fraternitatis announces the existence of the Brotherhood of the Rose Cross and invites learned men to contact them.

label: Elaborates on brotherhood
evidence: The Confessio Fraternitatis elaborates on the Brotherhood's philosophical principles and defends it against critics.

label: Narrates journey
evidence: The Chymical Wedding tells the allegorical story of Christian Rosenkreutz's seven-day journey of spiritual transformation.

label: Recounts life story
evidence: The Fama Fraternitatis contains the legendary biography of Christian Rosenkreutz, the purported founder of the brotherhood.

label: Legendary founder
evidence: According to the manifestos, Christian Rosenkreutz founded the Rosicrucian Brotherhood after traveling to the East and learning secret wisdom. Both are likely literary/symbolic creations.

label: Founder
evidence: Paracelsus's revolutionary medical and philosophical innovations gave rise to the Paracelsian movement.

label: Key disseminator
evidence: Bodenstein published over 40 Paracelsian titles beginning in 1560, making Paracelsian texts widely available.

label: Theoretical exponent
evidence: Severinus's Idea Medicinae Philosophicae (1571) provided a systematic theoretical foundation for Paracelsianism.

label: Influential proponent
evidence: Croll's Basilica Chymica (1609) was widely read and helped establish iatrochemistry as a legitimate medical approach.

label: Academic synthesizer
evidence: Sennert reconciled Galenic medicine with Paracelsian innovations, helping legitimize chemical remedies in academic medicine.

label: First chemistry professor
evidence: Hartmann was appointed the first professor of Chymiatrie at Marburg in 1609, institutionalizing Paracelsian chemical medicine.

label: Integrated Paracelsian ideas
evidence: Hess practiced Paracelsian medicine and integrated Paracelsianism into his prophetic and reformist vision that shaped the Rosicrucian manifestos.

label: Precursor figure
evidence: Weigel's mystical writings on inner spirituality and the 'inner church' were foundational for Christian theosophy.

label: Devotional writer
evidence: Arndt's True Christianity emphasized inner moral transformation, drawing on medieval mystical traditions and influencing later theosophy.

label: Central figure
evidence: Boehme is considered the central figure of Christian theosophy, synthesizing theology with nature mysticism and alchemical symbolism.

label: Later exponent
evidence: Gichtel continued the theosophical tradition by editing Boehme's works and founding the Gichtelians.

label: Founder
evidence: Weigelianism is the movement inspired by Valentin Weigel's posthumously published mystical writings.

label: Founder
evidence: Caspar Schwenckfeld founded the Schwenckfelder movement emphasizing spiritual regeneration and inner faith.

label: Founder
evidence: Severinus's Idea Medicinae Philosophicae (1571) established the theoretical school known as Severinian Paracelsianism.

label: Follower
evidence: Croll's work built on Severinian theoretical foundations for Paracelsian medicine.

label: Academic follower
evidence: Sennert's synthetic approach was influenced by Severinian systematization of Paracelsian thought.

label: Major apologist
evidence: Maier was the most important early Rosicrucian apologist, publishing defenses like Themis Aurea (1618) and the emblem book Atalanta Fugiens (1617).

label: English defender
evidence: Fludd published Apologia Compendiaria (1616) and Tractatus Apologeticus (1617) defending the Rosicrucian Brotherhood.

label: Critic
evidence: Libavius published Analysis Confessionis (1615) systematically critiquing the Rosicrucian manifestos.

label: First respondent
evidence: Haslmayr was the first known commentator on the Rosicrucian manifestos, claiming to have seen the Fama in manuscript in 1612.

label: Rosicrucian author
evidence: Mögling published Rosicrucian works including Speculum Sophicum Rhodostauroticum (1618) under the pseudonym Theophilus Schweighardt.

label: Major figure
evidence: Dee's Monas Hieroglyphica (1564) presented a unified Hermetic symbol and his work exemplifies Renaissance Hermeticism.

label: Major figure
evidence: Fludd's Utriusque Cosmi Historia presented a comprehensive Hermetic-Neoplatonic worldview.

label: Bridge figure
evidence: Khunrath's Amphitheatrum combined Paracelsian alchemy with Hermetic philosophy, bridging Dee's magical tradition and later Rosicrucianism.

label: Student
evidence: Andreae studied theology and mathematics at the University of Tübingen.

label: Resident scholar
evidence: Hess was a jurist residing in Tübingen with connections to the university community.

label: Professor of law
evidence: Besold was professor of jurisprudence at the University of Tübingen.

label: Student
evidence: Kepler studied at the University of Tübingen, where he befriended Besold and studied under Mästlin.

label: Professor
evidence: Mästlin was professor of mathematics at the University of Tübingen, teaching both Kepler and Andreae.

label: Location
evidence: The University of Tübingen was founded in 1477 and remains in Tübingen.

label: First chemistry professor
evidence: Hartmann was appointed professor of Chymiatrie at Marburg in 1609, the first such professorship.

label: Academic
evidence: Petraeus worked at the University of Marburg, presiding over academic disputations on Paracelsian medicine.

label: Professor
evidence: Eglin became professor at the University of Marburg from 1606 after fleeing Zürich.

label: Professor
evidence: Cramer held an academic position as professor at the University of Marburg.

label: Location
evidence: The University of Marburg was the first Protestant university in Germany, founded in 1527.

label: Founder and director
evidence: Hartmann established the first public chemical laboratory at a European university under patronage of Moritz of Hesse-Kassel.

label: Collaborator
evidence: Petraeus collaborated with his father-in-law Hartmann at the Marburg laboratory.

label: Location
evidence: The Marburg Chemical Laboratory was established at the University of Marburg.

label: University facility
evidence: The chemical laboratory was part of the University of Marburg's teaching facilities.

label: Emperor
evidence: Rudolf II was Holy Roman Emperor from 1576 to 1612 and made Prague the center of his court.

label: Seeking patronage
evidence: Dee and Kelley visited Rudolf II's court in Prague seeking patronage for their esoteric work.

label: Court alchemist
evidence: After parting from Dee, Kelley remained in Bohemia as a prominent alchemist under Rudolf II's patronage.

label: Imperial Astronomer
evidence: Tycho Brahe became Imperial Court Astronomer under Rudolf II in Prague from 1599.

label: Imperial Mathematician
evidence: Kepler worked at Rudolf's court as assistant to Brahe and then as Imperial Astronomer.

label: Physician and counselor
evidence: On 19 September 1609 Maier entered the service of Emperor Rudolf II as his physician and imperial counselor.

label: Visitor
evidence: Khunrath visited Rudolf II's court in Prague where he met Edward Kelley.

label: Court connections
evidence: Croll had connections to Rudolf II's court in Prague.

label: Imperial capital
evidence: Rudolf II made Prague his principal residence and the center of his court.

label: Landgrave
evidence: Moritz of Hesse-Kassel was Landgrave of Hesse from 1592 to 1627.

label: Under patronage
evidence: Hartmann was appointed to the chemistry professorship under Moritz's patronage.

label: Court physician
evidence: Around 1619 Maier became physician to Landgrave Moritz of Hesse-Kassel.

label: Court location
evidence: Moritz's court was at Kassel, where the Rosicrucian manifestos were published.

label: Elector Palatine
evidence: Frederick V was Elector Palatine from 1610 and his court at Heidelberg was a center of Protestant hopes.

label: Electress
evidence: Elizabeth Stuart joined the Palatine court after her marriage to Frederick V in 1613.

label: Garden designer
evidence: De Caus designed the famous Hortus Palatinus at Heidelberg for Frederick V.

label: Court location
evidence: Frederick V's court was at Heidelberg until his acceptance of the Bohemian crown.

label: Noble patron
evidence: Vilém of Rožmberk was the head of the powerful Rosenberg family and a major patron of esoteric research.

label: Hosted
evidence: Vilém of Rožmberk hosted John Dee and Edward Kelley at his castle in Třeboň.

label: Court alchemist
evidence: Kelley lived at Vilém of Rožmberk's castle in Třeboň conducting alchemical work.

label: Castle location
evidence: The Rožmberk court was at Vilém's castle in Třeboň.

label: Publisher
evidence: The de Bry publishing house issued Robert Fludd's Utriusque Cosmi Historia in Oppenheim.

label: Publisher
evidence: The de Bry publishing house issued Michael Maier's Atalanta Fugiens in Oppenheim in 1617.

label: Court physician
evidence: On 19 September 1609 Maier entered the service of Emperor Rudolf II as his physician.

label: First holder
evidence: In 1609, Landgrave Moritz appointed Hartmann to a newly created chair for Chymiatrie at Marburg—the first such professorship.

label: Position location
evidence: The Professor of Chymiatrie position was created at the University of Marburg.

label: Personal acquaintance
evidence: Comenius knew Andreae personally and expressed admiration for his ideas about reform and higher learning. Andreae's works helped shape Comenius's thinking on universal education and social reform.

label: Early reader
evidence: Comenius read the Fama Fraternitatis in manuscript as early as 1612, while studying at Heidelberg. The Rosicrucian ideals of reform and universal wisdom influenced his development of pansophia.

label: University study
evidence: Comenius studied at the University of Heidelberg from 1611-1614, where he encountered Rosicrucian ideas.

label: Close collaborators
evidence: Comenius was Hartlib's major intellectual ally in promoting universal education and pansophia. Hartlib helped publish and circulate Comenius's ideas, including Pansophiae Prodromus (1639).

label: Reform collaborators
evidence: Comenius collaborated with Dury through the Hartlib Circle on educational and religious reform projects.

label: Final residence
evidence: Comenius spent his final years in Amsterdam, where he died on November 15, 1670.
Comenius wrote Pansophiae Prodromus, published in London in 1639 with Hartlib's assistance.
Comenius wrote Via Lucis during his 1641 visit to England at Hartlib's invitation.
Comenius wrote Didactica Magna, originally in Czech, later published in Latin in 1657.

label: Intellectual influence
evidence: Though not an organizer of the circle, Comenius's ideas of pansophia and universal reform deeply influenced the Hartlib Circle's projects.

label: Central organizer
evidence: Hartlib was the central hub of the correspondence network that bears his name, serving as an intelligencer and knowledge broker.

label: Close collaborators
evidence: Hartlib and Dury were close friends and working partners from their meeting in Elbing. They collaborated on Protestant unity, educational reform, and published The Reformed School (1648) together.

label: Published in London
evidence: Hartlib helped publish and circulate Comenius's Pansophiae Prodromus in London in 1639.

label: Alchemical correspondence
evidence: Hartlib recorded Henshaw's claim to have discovered the alkahest and corresponded with him about alchemical and reform projects.

label: Birthplace
evidence: Hartlib was born around 1600 in Elbing, Prussia to a merchant family.

label: Primary residence
evidence: Hartlib moved to England around 1628 and settled in London, where he conducted his intelligencing activities until his death.

label: Core member
evidence: Dury was a core member of the Hartlib Circle from its inception, working on Protestant ecumenism and educational reform.

label: Met Hartlib
evidence: Dury worked among Protestant communities in Elbing between 1624-1626, where he met Samuel Hartlib.

label: Retirement
evidence: Dury settled in Kassel, Hesse-Kassel in 1661, where he remained until his death in 1680.
Dury co-authored The Reformed School (1648) with Hartlib.
Hartlib co-authored The Reformed School (1648) with Dury.
Dury wrote The Reformed Librarie-Keeper in 1650.
Heydon wrote The Holy Guide, published in 1662.

label: Posthumous influence
evidence: Heydon's Holy Guide borrows heavily from Bacon's New Atlantis, equating Bacon's Salomon's House with a Rosicrucian Temple.

label: Criticized
evidence: Elias Ashmole called Heydon 'an ignoramus and a cheate.'
Heydon was born in London and lived there throughout his life.

label: Later Rosicrucian author
evidence: Heydon's Rosicrucian publications represent a later phase of English engagement with Rosicrucian ideas.

label: Correspondent
evidence: Henshaw was in correspondence with Hartlib, discussing alchemical projects and plans for a 'Christian Learned Society.'

label: Alchemical collaboration
evidence: Thomas Vaughan lived with Henshaw at his house in Kensington while conducting alchemical experiments.

label: Used library
evidence: Elias Ashmole made use of Henshaw's extensive alchemical library for his Theatrum Chemicum Britannicum.
Henshaw was born in London and lived there (including Kensington) throughout his life.

label: Center of network
evidence: The Hartlib Circle was centered on Hartlib's activities in London, though its correspondence network spanned Europe.

label: Exile
evidence: Gichtel lived in Amsterdam in exile, where he edited and published Boehme's collected works.
